description: From Middle English sensat, from Late Latin sensatus (“able to sense”), from sensus (“sense”).

adjectives.description: sensate (comparative more sensate, superlative most sensate)

entries.meaning: Perceived by one or more of the senses.
Having the ability to sense things physically.
Felt or apprehended through a sense, or the senses.
examples: To say that Volitions which are acts of the Intellectual Soul must be sensate, and so make a Species on the phantasie, as sensate things do

verbs.description: sensate (third-person singular simple present sensates, present participle sensating, simple past and past participle sensated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To feel or apprehend by means of the senses; to perceive.
examples: to sensate light, or an odour
